title-group.article-title: Capital Investment Decisions under Economies of Scale in Flotation Costs

abstract.p: Flotation costs, like other financial market imperfections, make capital budgeting and financing decisions interdependent. In this paper, we present a mathematical programming model that specifically addresses this interdependency. The model presented determines optimal capital investment and financing profiles for a firm facing project indivisibilities and economies of scale in flotation costs. It is assumed that the flotation cost rates available to the firm depend on achieving certain investment thresholds in each time period. These costs include payments to third parties (e.g., investment bankers) for floating a bond or an equity issue, as well as organizational and related costs of negotiating a loan or line of credit. We report computational experience with our approach using commercially available computer software. Our formulation indicates that it is often advantageous to float a larger issue than necessary for current period investment and carry over excess funds for use in future periods. We also demonstrate the desirability of considering multiple time periods for funds acquisition and project selection when flotation costs are present.
